instruction: Explain the definition/principle of Clause 418 regarding joint property
input: According to Clause 418, what is a joint property?
output: Clause 418 states that a joint property refers to an asset or land owned by two or more individuals jointly. This clause establishes the conditions under which such properties can be sold and transferred. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the rights granted by Clause 418 to owners of a joint property
input: According to Clause 418, what rights do owners of joint property have?
output: Clause 418 grants owners of joint property the right to sell and transfer their respective shares with the consent of all other owners (sub-section 1). An owner may also transfer their share even if not all other owners agree, but the sale must be made according to the stipulated procedures. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the obligations imposed on owners of a joint property by Clause 418
input: According to Clause 418, what duties do owners of joint property have towards each other?
output: Clause 418 imposes an obligation on all owners of a joint property to act in good faith when transferring their shares. The clause also states that if it is technically not possible to separate one owner's share from the joint property, and another owner intends to acquire it, that owner shall be entitled to obtain it at the price mutually agreed upon between the owners (sub-section 3). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Illustrate how Clause 418 applies in practice for the sale of a joint property
input: According to Clause 418, what happens when owners of a joint property decide to sell it?
output: Clause 418 states that if all owners of a joint property agree to sell it, the property can be sold, and the proceeds shall be divided among the owners according to their respective shares. However, even if not all owners agree, any owner may transfer their share following the stipulated procedures (sub-section 2). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify exceptions or limitations in Clause 418 regarding the sale of a joint property
input: According to Clause 418, are there any conditions under which the sale of a joint property is not allowed?
output: Clause 418 does not explicitly state conditions under which the sale of a joint property is not allowed. However, it is essential to note that any transfer made in contravention of sub-section (1) will only be valid for the extent of the right or portion of the transferor (sub-section 6). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Outline the procedural steps involved in selling a joint property according to Clause 418
input: According to Clause 418, what are the steps involved in selling a joint property?
output: Clause 418 does not explicitly outline specific procedural steps for selling a joint property. However, it is essential that all owners of the joint property agree to the sale (sub-section 1), or follow the stipulated procedures if only some of the owners wish to sell their shares. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the principle in Clause 419(a) regarding transferring property in common
input: According to Clause 419(a), who needs consent for transferring a property in common?
output: Clause 419 states that no person shall transfer a property in common without obtaining written consent of the coparceners in common. This rule aims to prevent unilateral alterations to joint properties among family members. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze how Clause 419(b) impacts witnesses in deed of transfer
input: According to Clause 419(b), what is the significance of a coparcener who acts as a witness in the deed of transfer?
output: Clause 419 states that if a coparcener of the joint family is a witness to the deed of transfer of a property in common, consent of that coparcener shall be deemed to have been obtained. This exemption allows for transactions to proceed even when actual consent may not be easily attainable. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the implications of Clause 419(c) in case of transfer contravention
input: What happens if someone transfers a property in common in violation of Clause 419(c)?
output: Clause 419 states that if any person transfers a property in common in contravention of sub-section (1), the transfer of title only to the extent of such right or portion that person has in that property shall be valid. However, the concerned coparcener shall be entitled to get back the property transferred in excess of such right or portion. This provision provides recourse for aggrieved coparceners when unlawful transactions occur. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: What rights are granted to coparceners by Clause 419?
input: According to Clause 419, what rights do coparceners have when it comes to transferring property in common?
output: Clause 419 states that coparceners have the right to give or withhold consent before any property in common is transferred. They also have the right to reclaim any portion of property transferred without their permission, provided they have a valid claim. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the practical application of Clause 419
input: In real-world scenarios, how does Clause 419 impact property transactions among family members?
output: Clause 419 has significant implications for jointly owned properties within families. It requires that all coparceners give their written consent before such properties can be transferred to another person. This ensures fairness and prevents one member from making unilateral decisions that may impact the whole family. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Are there any exceptions or limitations in Clause 419?
input: Does Clause 419 have any provisions for exemptions or special cases?
output: Clause 419 does include some exceptions. For example, if a coparcener acts as a witness to the deed of transfer, their consent is deemed to be obtained. Additionally, the validity of the transfer only extends to the portion owned by the transferee. The remaining coparceners can seek to recover any excess property transferred unlawfully. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain what Clause 420 establishes regarding selling property in common
input: According to Clause 420, what are the rules for selling property in common?
output: Clause 420 states that a person acting as the head of family may sell whole or half of the property in common (depending on whether it is movable or immovable) for household purposes without the consent of others, even if there are rules against it in Section 419. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the rights granted to individuals under Clause 420
input: According to Clause 420, what rights does a person acting as the head of family have to sell property in common?
output: Clause 420 grants the right to the person acting as the head of family to sell whole or half of the property in common (depending on whether it is movable or immovable) for household purposes without the consent of others, even if there are rules against it in Section 419. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify the obligations imposed by Clause 420
input: According to Clause 420, what duties does a person have when selling property in common?
output: Clause 420 imposes the obligation on the person acting as the head of family to use the proceeds from selling property in common for household purposes. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain how Clause 420 applies in practice
input: According to Clause 420, how can a person acting as the head of family utilize the provision for selling property in common?
output: Clause 420 allows a person acting as the head of family to sell whole or half of the property in common (depending on whether it is movable or immovable) for household purposes without the consent of others, even if there are rules against it in Section 419. It's essential to understand that this provision should be used responsibly and ethically. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze exceptions to Clause 420
input: Are there any limitations or exceptions to Clause 420 regarding selling property in common?
output: Clause 420 grants the person acting as the head of family the right to sell whole or half of the property in common (depending on whether it is movable or immovable) for household purposes without the consent of others, even if there are rules against it in Section 419. However, it's crucial to note that any misuse of this provision may lead to legal consequences. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the procedural steps for selling property in common under Clause 420
input: According to Clause 420, what are the steps to follow when selling property in common?
output: Clause 420 does not provide specific procedural steps for selling property in common. It grants the person acting as the head of family the right to sell whole or half of the property in common (depending on whether it is movable or immovable) for household purposes without the consent of others, even if there are rules against it in Section 419. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the legal principle of Clause 421(a) regarding prohibition of transferring other's property
input: According to Clause 421(a), what are the rules for transferring someone else's property?
output: Clause 421 states that a person should not transfer property in which another has right and ownership. Such transfers made contrary to this rule are void (Clause 421(2)). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the consequences of violating Clause 421(a) in property transfer
input: What happens if a person transfers someone else's property against Clause 421(a)?
output: Clause 421 states that if a person transfers a property in contravention of sub-section (1), such deed or transaction shall be void (Clause 421(2)). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the obligation of the original owner under Clause 421(a) when claiming property transferred in violation
input: According to Clause 421(a), what should a real owner do if they find out their property was unlawfully transferred?
output: Clause 421 states that if the real owner makes a claim in the property transferred pursuant to sub-section (1), the transferee of such property shall return it to the concerned owner (Clause 421(3)). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain Clause 421(b) regarding finding lost or stolen properties
input: What does Clause 421(b) say about claiming lost or stolen property?
output: Clause 421 states that if a person finds any lost or stolen property, the owner of such property may claim it within three years after the date on which the property was lost or stolen (Clause 421(4)). The finder shall return the property to the owner by collecting the amount of expenses incurred during its preservation or maintenance (Clause 421(5)). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze exceptions to Clause 421(b) regarding acquired stolen or lost properties
input: Are there any exceptions in Clause 421(b) when a person can keep a found stolen property?
output: Clause 421 states that notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (4), if a person has acquired any stolen or lost property by way of purchase at a public market or auction or bidding made publicly by any person or body, the person shall not be bound to return such property to the real owner unless and until he or she obtains the real value of such property and the fees or amount, if any, paid by him or her in the acquisition of such property (Clause 421(6)). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Determine the legal status of a transferred property under Clause 421
input: What is the validity of a transfer that violates Clause 421?
output: Clause 421 states that any transfer made in contravention of sub-section (1) shall be void (Clause 421(2)). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the principle of Clause 422 regarding the prohibition of transferring property in duplication
input: According to Clause 422, what does it mean to prohibit the transferring of property in duplication?
output: Clause 422 states that no person shall re-transfer a property they have already transferred to another person. This principle aims to prevent double ownership and potential disputes over property rights. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the exceptions to Clause 422's prohibition of transferring property in duplication
input: Are there any circumstances under which Clause 422 allows for re-transferring a property?
output: Clause 422 states that if a person transfers a property contrary to sub-section (1), the earlier transfer may still be valid, depending on whether it involves an immovable or movable property. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the rights granted by Clause 422 regarding the transfer of properties
input: What rights does Clause 422 provide to individuals in relation to transferring their properties?
output: Clause 422 grants a person the right to transfer their property once, but prohibits re-transfer. If re-transfer is done despite this prohibition, the earlier transfer may still be valid depending on the nature of the property. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify the obligations imposed by Clause 422 regarding the transfer of properties
input: What duties does Clause 422 impose on individuals with respect to property transfers?
output: Clause 422 imposes an obligation not to re-transfer a property once it has been transferred. Violating this obligation may result in the earlier transfer becoming valid, depending on the nature of the property. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Illustrate how Clause 422 applies in a practical scenario
input: Provide an example of a situation where Clause 422 would come into play during the transfer of property
output: In a situation where a person has already transferred immovable property to someone, and attempts to re-transfer it to another party, Clause 422 may apply. If the earlier transfer was registered first, the later attempt to re-transfer would be invalid. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Detail the procedural steps involved in Clause 422
input: What are the steps to follow when transferring property according to Clause 422?
output: To transfer property according to Clause 422, one should ensure they have not previously transferred the same property. If a later transfer is attempted despite a previous one, the earlier transfer may still be valid if it involves immovable property. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Define the legal restriction established by Clause 423 on donation or gift of property
input: According to Clause 423, what is prohibited regarding the giving away of assets under guardianship or curatorship?
output: Clause 423 states that no guardian or curator may donate or give away any property belonging to the person under their care to any individual. This restriction aims to protect the rights and interests of the ward or client. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Determine the rights of wards/clients as per Clause 423
input: What does Clause 423 establish in terms of rights for individuals under guardianship or curatorship?
output: Clause 423 grants the right to retain their property while under a guardian or curator's care. This clause is intended to safeguard the assets and financial wellbeing of wards and clients. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify the duties imposed on guardians/curators as per Clause 423
input: According to Clause 423, what are the responsibilities of a guardian or curator regarding property belonging to their ward or client?
output: Clause 423 imposes the duty on guardians and curators not to donate or give away any property that belongs to the person under their care. This obligation is crucial for ensuring the integrity and preservation of the ward's or client's assets. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Illustrate a practical application of Clause 423
input: How might Clause 423 be applied in a real-life situation?
output: For example, if a guardian or curator attempts to transfer property belonging to their ward or client to themselves or another individual, they would be in violation of Clause 423. The prohibition of such donations serves to maintain the integrity of the ward's or client's estate. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify any limitations or exceptions in Clause 423
input: Are there any situations where donating property by a guardian or curator would be allowed, according to Clause 423?
output: There may be exemptions or special circumstances where donations could be made while under guardianship or curatorship. However, it's essential to consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation in these cases. Generally, any exceptions should adhere to the overarching goal of protecting the rights and interests of wards and clients.

instruction: Outline procedural steps for enforcing Clause 423
input: What are the steps one might take to enforce Clause 423 if a guardian or curator attempts to donate prohibited property?
output: If a violation of Clause 423 is suspected, it's recommended to consult legal counsel and potentially file a petition with the relevant court to address the issue. The specific procedural steps may vary depending on the circumstances and jurisdiction. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the compensation a purchaser is entitled to when a property transfer under Clause 424(1) is invalid
input: According to Clause 424(1), what happens if a property sale transfer is deemed invalid?
output: Clause 424 states that in such a case, the purchaser is entitled to recover from the transferor the amount paid for the property. This includes an interest set by yearly ten percent of the amount and any registration or other fees paid for the transfer. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the rights of a person making a structure in Clause 424(2) when their property transfer is invalid
input: According to Clause 424(2), what can a person do if they made a structure on a property whose transfer is deemed invalid?
output: Clause 424 states that this individual may demolish and take away the structure within six months of the transfer being declared invalid. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the compensation for aggrieved parties under Clause 424(3) when a property transfer violates certain sections
input: According to Clause 424(3), what compensation can be claimed by someone affected by an invalid property transfer that violates specific sections?
output: Clause 424 states that in such cases, the aggrieved person is entitled to a reasonable compensation for actual loss and damage suffered from the transferor. This is in addition to the amount referred to in sub-section (1). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the entitlement to compensation under Clause 424(4) when a donation or gift cannot be used
input: According to Clause 424(4), what is the entitlement to compensation when a person is unable to use a property due to reasons mentioned in this chapter?
output: Clause 424 states that under such circumstances, the person is entitled to get reasonable compensation from the person making the donation or gift. However, compensation cannot be recovered in the case of a testamentary gift being void. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Define when a person is not entitled to recovery under Clause 424(5)
input: According to Clause 424(5), under what circumstances will a person not be eligible for the amounts mentioned in sub-sections (1), (3) and (4)?
output: Clause 424 states that a person who obtains a property knowingly that it was someone else's property or stolen property, or already transferred to another person, will not be entitled to recover the amounts mentioned in sub-sections (1), (3) and (4). Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the rights of an attorney in Clause 425(1) when selling or transferring immovable property
input: According to Clause 425, what powers does an authorized attorney have when it comes to selling and transferring immovable property?
output: Clause 425 states that an authorized attorney, appointed according to law, may sell and transfer the immovable property on behalf of the person who is unable to appear in person before the concerned office. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the ability to sell movable property through an attorney or agent according to Clause 425(2)
input: According to Clause 425(2), how can a person sell their movable property?
output: Clause 425 states that a person may sell their movable property through their attorney or agent.

instruction: Explain how a body corporate can transfer property according to Clause 426(1)
input: According to Clause 426(1), what process must be followed by a body corporate to authorize a member or employee to transfer immovable property?
output: Clause 426 states that if a body corporate wants to transfer an immovable property, it must first give the power to do so by decision of its board of directors to any member or employee. This person can then transfer the property on behalf of the body corporate.

instruction: Analyze the rights and obligations for a member/employee in Clause 426(1)
input: What are the rights and duties of a member or employee under Clause 426(1) when transferring property on behalf of a body corporate?
output: According to Clause 426, a member or employee has the right to transfer immovable property on behalf of a body corporate if authorized by its board of directors. The duty lies with the person to ensure the transfer is made according to the body corporate's decision.

instruction: Describe the practical application of Clause 426(1)
input: How does Clause 426(1) impact the process of transferring property by a body corporate?
output: Clause 426(1) establishes that when a body corporate transfers an immovable property, it must follow a specific procedure where its board of directors gives the power to transfer the property to a member or employee. This rule provides clarity on who can act as an agent in such transactions.

instruction: Identify exceptions for Clause 426(1)
input: Are there any limitations or exceptions mentioned in Clause 426(1) for transferring property by a body corporate?
output: Clause 426(1) does not seem to provide any specific exceptions for transferring immovable property. However, it is always important to consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Outline the procedural steps in Clause 426(1)
input: What are the procedural steps a body corporate should follow when transferring property according to Clause 426(1)?
output: According to Clause 426(1), the procedure for transferring immovable property by a body corporate includes giving power by decision of its board of directors to any member or employee to transfer the property.

instruction: Explain how a body corporate can purchase property according to Clause 426(2)
input: According to Clause 426(2), what process must be followed by a body corporate while purchasing an immovable property?
output: Clause 426 states that if the procedure mentioned in sub-section (1) is fulfilled while purchasing or otherwise obtaining an immovable property in the name of a corporate body, the property may be purchased or obtained in the name of such a body.

instruction: Summarize Clause 426 and its relevance for bodies corporate
input: What does Clause 426 establish in relation to bodies corporate regarding property transactions?
output: Clause 426 sets forth the procedure that a body corporate must follow while purchasing or transferring immovable property. It grants power to its board of directors or employees to act on behalf of the body corporate for such transactions.

instruction: Explain the legal principle of Clause 427(a) regarding purchasing property on behalf of another
input: According to Clause 427(a), what conditions allow a person to purchase property on behalf of someone else?
output: Clause 427 states that if a person is unable to appear in person before the concerned office, they can authorize another competent individual as per Nepalese law to purchase or obtain a property in their name. This is allowed under Clause 427(a) except for circumstances set forth in Section 426. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the obligations of the attorney under Clause 427(a)
input: What duties does an attorney have according to Clause 427(a) when purchasing property on behalf of another?
output: Clause 427 states that an attorney purchasing or obtaining a property on behalf of someone else must act in good faith and adhere to the terms and conditions set forth under this Chapter. The attorney is responsible for ensuring the property transaction is legitimate and valid. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the rights of the person giving power of attorney under Clause 427(a)
input: What rights does a person have who gives a power of attorney to purchase property according to Clause 427(a)?
output: Clause 427 grants the right to the person who gives a power of attorney for purchasing or obtaining a property, that the property will be acquired in their name if the attorney complies with this Chapter's conditions. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the exceptions under Clause 427(a) related to purchasing property
input: Are there any circumstances where purchasing or obtaining a property under Clause 427(a) is not allowed?
output: Clause 427 states that exceptions for purchasing or obtaining a property on behalf of someone else under this clause are set forth in Section 426. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the procedural steps for purchasing property under Clause 427(a)
input: What specific steps must be followed to purchase a property using power of attorney according to Clause 427(a)?
output: Clause 427 states that to purchase or obtain a property on behalf of someone else, the attorney should provide a power of attorney accompanied by the principal's citizenship certificate. The attorney then proceeds with the transaction in accordance with this Chapter. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the consequences if Clause 427(a) conditions are not met
input: What happens if an attorney fails to comply with the requirements set forth in Clause 427(a) when purchasing property on behalf of someone else?
output: Clause 427 does not specify any specific consequences for an attorney who fails to comply with this Chapter's conditions. However, such non-compliance may result in the transaction being deemed invalid or unenforceable. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain what Clause 428 establishes regarding property acquisition in the name of an incompetent or quasi-competent person
input: According to Clause 428, can a guardian or curator purchase or obtain property for someone deemed incompetent or quasi-competent?
output: Clause 428 states that a guardian or curator may acquire any property by way of donation, gift, purchase, or otherwise for an incompetent, quasi-competent minor, a guardian, or a member of an undivided family for the baby in the womb under their guardianship or curatorship. This clause defines a means for such individuals to legally acquire property.

instruction: Provide an example application of Clause 428(a) in practice
input: According to Clause 428(a), how might a guardian acquire property for an incompetent person?
output: Clause 428(a) allows a guardian to purchase or obtain property on behalf of an incompetent individual. For instance, if a grandparent is appointed as the guardian of a minor child, they could buy a house in their name for the benefit of the child.

instruction: Analyze how Clause 428(b) applies to property acquisition for a baby in the womb
input: According to Clause 428(b), what rights does a guardian have regarding the purchase of property for an unborn child?
output: Clause 428(b) extends the right to acquire property to members of an undivided family for the baby in the womb under their guardianship or curatorship. This means that if a family member is expecting a child and another family member assumes the role of guardian, they can purchase property on behalf of the unborn child.

instruction: Identify the rights granted to an incompetent or quasi-competent person under Clause 428(a)
input: What rights does Clause 428(a) grant to an incompetent or quasi-competent individual?
output: Clause 428(a) grants the right for a guardian or curator to acquire property on behalf of an incompetent or quasi-competent person. This means that even though they cannot act independently, such individuals have a legal interest in the property acquired.

instruction: Describe the rights granted to an unborn child under Clause 428(b)
input: What rights does Clause 428(b) grant to an unborn child?
output: Clause 428(b) grants the right for a member of an undivided family to acquire property on behalf of the baby in the womb under their guardianship or curatorship. This means that even though the child is not yet born, they have a legal interest in the property acquired.

instruction: Identify any limitations or exceptions to Clause 428
input: Are there any conditions or restrictions on property acquisition under Clause 428?
output: Clause 428 does not specify any particular conditions or restrictions for acquiring property in the name of an incompetent or quasi-competent person, provided that it is done through donation, gift, purchase, or other legal means by a guardian or curator. However, specific laws and regulations may apply depending on the nature and value of the property involved.

instruction: Explain what Clause 429(a) establishes regarding property rights transfer in testament
input: According to Clause 429(a), what happens when someone transfers a property right with testamentary effect?
output: Clause 429(a) states that if a person transfers their right in a property to another person with testamentary effect and dies, the recipient must apply for the transmission of the property within six months after the transferor's death. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe how Clause 429(a) applies in practice
input: According to Clause 429(a), what steps should be followed when a property is transferred with testamentary effect?
output: Clause 429(a) outlines that after transferring a property right with testamentary effect, the recipient must submit an application accompanied by evidence to the concerned office within six months of the transferor's death for the transmission of the property. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the obligations imposed by Clause 429(b) after a property right is transferred with testamentary effect
input: According to Clause 429(b), what duties does the recipient have after obtaining a property through a testamentary transfer?
output: Clause 429(b) requires the recipient of a property obtained through a testamentary transfer to submit an application, accompanied by evidence, for the transmission of the property within six months after the transferor's death. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the procedure specified by Clause 429(c) for the transmission of property
input: According to Clause 429(c), what steps are involved in transmitting a property after a testamentary transfer?
output: Clause 429(c) outlines that the concerned office examines the deed and makes necessary inquiries as to whether the deed executor has died or not, and if the deed is void. If it appears that the transferor has died without voiding the deed, the property is transmitted to the applicant. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Discuss the exceptions mentioned in Clause 429(c) for property transmission
input: According to Clause 429(c), are there any conditions or limitations for transmitting a property after a testamentary transfer?
output: Clause 429(c) mentions that if an application is submitted after the expiration of the six-month time limit, the office may transmit the property by collecting fees for each year past the deadline. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Summarize Clause 429 and its implications
input: What does Clause 429 establish regarding property rights transfer in testament?
output: Clause 429 establishes a process for transmitting a property right obtained through testamentary effect. The recipient must apply for the transmission within six months after the transferor's death, and the concerned office examines the deed and makes necessary inquiries. If it appears that the transferor has died without voiding the deed, the property is transmitted to the applicant. If an application is submitted late, fees may be collected for each year past the deadline. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the principle of Clause 430(a) regarding the seller's responsibility for property quality
input: According to Clause 430(a), what are the seller's obligations when it comes to the condition of the sold property?
output: Clause 430 states that a seller is not allowed to claim for damage, destruction or low quality in a property they have already sold to another person. However, if the sale was made through misrepresentation or deviation from the specifics listed in the deed, the purchaser is entitled to compensation for these discrepancies. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze Clause 430(a) application in a scenario of misrepresentation
input: According to Clause 430(a), what happens when the seller deliberately hides property defects?
output: Clause 430 states that a seller who intentionally conceals property defects and then sells the property will not be protected from claims of damage, destruction, or low quality. The purchaser is entitled to compensation for any such discrepancies. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify the rights granted by Clause 430(a) in case of deceitful sales
input: What recourse does a buyer have if they purchase property based on false representations made by the seller according to Clause 430(a)?
output: Clause 430 grants buyers the right to seek compensation if they purchased property under false representations from the seller. The buyer can demand compensation for any damage, destruction, or low quality that was not disclosed at the time of sale. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the obligations imposed on buyers according to Clause 430(a)
input: What are a buyer's responsibilities when it comes to verifying property quality, as stated in Clause 430(a)?
output: Clause 430 does not impose any specific obligations on buyers regarding the verification of property quality. However, it is advisable for buyers to thoroughly examine properties before making a purchase, or seek professional advice when necessary. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain how Clause 430(a) interacts with the law of contract in property transactions
input: How does Clause 430(a) impact the standard of care expected from sellers and buyers during a property transaction?
output: Clause 430 affects the law of contract by imposing stricter standards on sellers regarding the truthfulness and accuracy of information they provide about the properties they are selling. Buyers, on the other hand, should exercise reasonable care when assessing the properties they intend to purchase. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Identify any exceptions in Clause 430(a) for property claims
input: Are there any instances where a seller can claim for damage, destruction, or low quality according to Clause 430(a)?
output: Clause 430 allows a seller to make a claim of damage, destruction, or low quality if the sale was made through misrepresentation or deviation from the specifics listed in the deed. In such cases, the purchaser is entitled to compensation for these discrepancies. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Define the principle of exchanging property as per Clause 431
input: According to Clause 431(a), what does it mean for property to be exchanged?
output: Clause 431 states that property may be exchanged. This allows any person to exchange their own property with another person, either with or without adding any amount. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the rights granted by Clause 431 when exchanging property
input: According to Clause 431(a), what rights do individuals have when they exchange their property?
output: Clause 431 grants individuals the right to exchange their own property with another person, either with or without adding any amount. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: List obligations imposed by Clause 431 when exchanging property
input: According to Clause 431(a), what duties does one need to fulfill when exchanging their property?
output: Clause 431 imposes no specific obligations on individuals when they exchange their own property with another person, either with or without adding any amount. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe how Clause 431 applies in practice when exchanging property
input: According to Clause 431(a), what does it mean in practical terms when property is exchanged?

instruction: Analyze the rights of creditors after the expiration of the period in Clause 443(1)
input: What can a creditor do after the five-year period mentioned in Clause 443(1) expires?
output: According to Clause 443, if the maximum period of mortgage without possession has expired, the property may be possessed for a period not exceeding ten years. instruction: Describe the implications of not redeeming a mortgaged property within the period in Clause 443(4)
input: What happens if the property given in mortgage without possession is not redeemed within the period of ten years as mentioned in Clause 443(4)?
output: According to Clause 443, if a mortgaged property is not redeemed within the ten-year period after taking possession under subsection (3), the relevant deed shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond. This means that the mortgage no longer secures the loan and becomes simply a promise to pay, with no right of possession for the creditor. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the restriction on taking action for effecting possession under Clause 443(2)
input: According to Clause 443(a), what actions are restricted for a creditor with regards to taking possession of a mortgaged property?
output: Clause 443 states that no creditor is entitled to take action for effecting possession in the property in mortgage without possession or having recovery of the related loan from the debtor prior to the completion of the period referred to in sub-section (1). This means that a creditor cannot attempt to seize or take control of a mortgaged property before the five-year period mentioned in subsection (1) has expired, or if they have not recovered the loan amount from the debtor. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the consequences of violating the restriction on taking possession under Clause 443(2)
input: What happens if a creditor takes action to effect possession in violation of Clause 443(a)?

If a creditor violates this restriction by taking possession of the property or attempting to recover the loan before the five-year period has elapsed, they may face legal consequences. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the principle of Clause 444 regarding redemption of mortgaged property
input: According to Clause 444, how can a debtor redeem their property from a creditor?

input: According to Clause 444(2), what happens if the property mortgaged is cultivable land and crops have already been planted by the creditor?

input: According to Clause 444, what are the steps a debtor should follow to redeem their mortgaged property?
output: While Clause 444 does not specify any particular procedural steps, it allows the debtor to redeem their mortgaged property by repaying the loan and interest (if applicable) to the creditor. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe what right is granted by Clause 445(1) regarding remortgaging a property
input: According to Clause 445(1), what privilege does the mortgage holder have to remortgage their property?
output: Clause 445 states that a person who has obtained a property in mortgage can remortgage such property or any part thereof to another person in consideration for an amount which is equal to, or lesser than, the amount specified in the deed of mortgage. This right allows them to secure additional funds against their mortgaged property. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain any conditions imposed by Clause 445(1) on remortgaging a property
input: According to Clause 445(1), are there any constraints related to the remortgage of a property?
output: Clause 445(1) states that before a mortgaged property can be remortgaged, the mortgaged property shall not be the object of re-mortgage prior to the existence of the possessory right in such property. This means the mortgage holder must have full control and ownership of the property before it can be remortgaged. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Detail the consequences if Clause 445(1) conditions are not met
input: What happens if a mortgaged property is remortgaged before the possessory right exists, according to Clause 445(1)?
output: Clause 445 states that a transaction of remortgage made inconsistent with the terms of the mortgage shall ipso facto be void to the extent of such inconsistency. This means if the mortgaged property is remortgaged before the possessory right exists, the re-mortgage will not be valid and may face legal challenges. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Elaborate on the period of possession and enjoyment under Clause 445(1)
input: According to Clause 445(1), what is the maximum duration of possession and enjoyment for a re-mortgage?
output: Clause 445 states that the period of possession and enjoyment of the re-mortgage given pursuant to sub-section (1) shall not exceed the period of possession and enjoyment under the mortgage. This means the duration of a re-mortgage is limited by the original mortgage agreement. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the procedure for redeeming the property remortgaged according to Clause 445(1)
input: How can the debtor redeem a property re-mortgaged pursuant to Clause 445(1)?
output: Clause 445 states that if the debtor who has right and ownership in the property intends to redeem the property re-mortgaged pursuant to sub-section (1), they may redeem the property upon payment of the price directly from the re-mortgagee if the price of the re-mortgage is equal to the original price. If such price is less than the original price, the redemption must be made through the original mortgagee. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the limitation on the period of possession and enjoyment under Clause 445(2)
input: What restrictions does Clause 445(2) place on the duration of re-mortgage?
output: Clause 445 states that the period of possession and enjoyment under the re-mortgage given pursuant to sub-section (1) shall not exceed the period of possession and enjoyment under the mortgage. This means the duration of a re-mortgage cannot exceed the original mortgage agreement's duration. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Elaborate on the deed of re-mortgage being equivalent to an unsecured bond according to Clause 445(5)
input: According to Clause 445(5), what is the nature of the deed of a re-mortgage if the creditor is not entitled to possess the property?
output: Clause 445 states that if the creditor is not entitled to possess the property re-mortgaged pursuant to this Chapter, the deed of such a re-mortgage shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali). This means the creditor cannot claim any security or collateral for the loan and can only pursue legal action for repayment. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the definition of mortgaging by a third party on behalf of the debtor according to Clause 447
input: According to Clause 447, what does it mean for a third party to mortgage property on behalf of the debtor?

input: What rights does the creditor have if a property is mortgaged by a third party on behalf of the debtor according to Clause 447?

instruction: Explain the legal principle of Clause 452 regarding property being mortgaged or transferred in duplication
input: According to Clause 452, what does it mean for a property to be mortgaged or transferred in duplication?
output: Clause 452 states that once a property is mortgaged, it cannot be mortgaged or transferred again to another person. This principle prevents the creation of multiple claims on the same property.

instruction: Identify the rights granted by Clause 452(1) regarding mortgaging properties
input: What rights does Clause 452(1) grant in relation to mortgage of a property?
output: Clause 452(1) grants the right for a previously mortgaged property not to be mortgaged or transferred again, ensuring that there are no multiple claims on the same property.

instruction: List the obligations imposed by Clause 452(1) regarding the transfer of mortgaged properties
input: What obligations does Clause 452(1) impose when trying to transfer a previously mortgaged property?
output: Clause 452(1) imposes an obligation not to mortgage or transfer again a previously mortgaged property. Violating this provision may lead to the subsequent deed being deemed void.

instruction: Describe how Clause 452(2) applies when there is a violation of the rule against duplicative mortgages
input: How does Clause 452(2) address the situation where someone mortgages a property in duplication?
output: Clause 452(2) states that if a person mortgages a property in duplication, the deed registered at an earlier date shall be valid and the subsequent deed shall ipso facto be void.

instruction: Identify exceptions to the rule of Clause 452 regarding duplicative mortgages
input: What are the exceptions outlined in Clause 452 when it comes to mortgaging properties in duplication?
output: Clause 452 provides exceptions for situations where the first deed is providing for a transfer of title instead of a mortgage (Clause 452(4)). In these cases, the transferee may be entitled to establish the title by making repayment of loan in accordance with the first deed.

instruction: Describe the procedure for establishing possessory right under Clause 452(6)
input: How is the possessory right established according to Clause 452(6) in the event of a deed of mortgage in duplication?
output: Clause 452(6) states that if there is a failure to establish the possessory right, the creditor's amount shall be equivalent to an unsecured bond (Kapali). However, if the first deed provides for mortgage with possession (Bhogbhandhaki), the possessory right must be established within two years from the date of the first deed. Similarly, if the first deed provides for mortgage without possessory right (Drishtibandhaki), the possessory right must be established within two years from the date of entitlement to the possessory right.

instruction: Identify the penalties outlined in Clause 452 for executing a deed in duplication
input: What penalties does Clause 452 impose on someone who executes a deed in duplication?

input: According to Clause 489, what happens when the concerned Local Level issues a receipt for a lost or destroyed deed?
output: Clause 489 states that if an application is made pursuant to sub-section (1), the concerned Local Level shall draw up a receipt setting out the matter and issue the receipt, sealed with the stamp of the office, to the applicant.

instruction: Describe the procedure for preparing a new deed when the deed executor is alive and consents according to Clause 489(3)
input: According to Clause 489, what happens if the deed executor is alive and consents to execute another deed indicating that the original one was lost or destroyed due to a force majeure event?
output: Clause 489 states that if an application is made pursuant to sub-section (1), the Local Level shall summon the presence of the deed executor, if he or she is alive, and of the nearest heir, if such executor is not alive, within seven days, and cause a deed to be prepared as per the original deed, if he or she so consents, and authenticate such deed and deliver it to the applicant.

instruction: Explain the legal recourse for a creditor when the deed executor does not consent to execute another deed according to Clause 489(4)
input: According to Clause 489, what happens if the deed executor does not consent to execute another deed indicating that the original one was lost or destroyed due to a force majeure event?
output: Clause 489 states that if the deed executor does not consent to execute another deed pursuant to sub-section (3), the creditor shall make a lawsuit and maintain his or her right, showing the evidence of the loss of deed or occurrence of the force majeure event, within thirty-five days of the expiry of that time-limit.

instruction: Describe the rights gained by the applicant after going through the procedure according to Clause 489
input: According to Clause 489, what are the rights gained by the applicant if they follow the specified procedure?
output: Clause 489 states that the applicant receives a new authenticated deed after the procedure, replacing the lost or destroyed one due to force majeure event.

instruction: Explain the procedure when the receiver can't possess goods due to imperfection according to Clause 490(1)
input: According to Clause 490(1), what should a receiver do if they can't keep the goods because of imperfections?
output: Clause 490 states that if the receiver of any goods transacted with specification of price is not able to possess the goods due to the fact that the goods do not correspond to that set forth in the deed or are imperfect for any reason, they shall give a notice thereof to the giver of goods within thirty-five days of such transaction. Consult The Muluki Ain (National Civil Code), 2017 AD, Nepal.

instruction: Analyze the condition for an exchange of goods according to Clause 490(2)
input: According to Clause 490(2), when should an exchange of goods take place?
output: Clause 490 states that if a notice is received from the receiver of goods pursuant to sub-section (1) and his or her statement appears to be reasonable, the exchange of goods shall be made if the giver has similar other goods. If the giver does not have such goods, they shall get back their goods and cancel the deed executed in relation to such transaction. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe the options for a giver who refuses to exchange or take back goods according to Clause 490(2)
input: According to Clause 490(2), what happens if the giver of goods refuses to exchange or take back the goods?
output: Clause 490 states that if the giver of goods refuses to exchange or take back the goods pursuant to sub-section (2), the receiver of goods may make a lawsuit to have recovery of an amount equivalent to the price of such goods and a reasonable compensation for the loss and damage caused to them. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the condition for voiding the transaction according to Clause 490(3)
input: According to Clause 490(3), what can make a transaction void?
output: Clause 490 states that if the giver of goods refuses to exchange or take back the goods pursuant to sub-section (2), the receiver of goods may also get such transaction to be void. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe exceptions to the procedure for returning imperfect goods in Clause 490

output: Clause 490 provides that except as otherwise provided for in the deed, these rules apply. It means that if there are specific terms mentioned in the agreement regarding the return of imperfect goods, those terms may supersede the ones outlined in this clause. Consult The Muluki Ain (National Civil Code), 2017 AD, Nepal.

instruction: Explain the principle of returning goods in original condition as per Clause 491(a)
input: According to Clause 491, what does it state about returning goods in their original condition?
output: Clause 491 states that if any person obtains or borrows goods owned by another for a specific purpose, they must return the same kind, quantity, and quality of goods after completing the purpose to the owner or possessor. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe exceptions provided in Clause 491(a) for returning goods
input: What are the exceptions, if any, mentioned in Clause 491 regarding the return of goods?
output: Clause 491 states that there may be exceptions to returning the same goods as provided in a deed. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Analyze the obligations imposed on the person obtaining goods under Clause 491(a)
input: According to Clause 491, what are the duties of a person who obtains goods from another?
output: Clause 491 imposes an obligation on the person who acquires or borrows goods to return them in the same kind, quantity, and quality after completing the purpose. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Explain the consequences of failing to return goods as per Clause 491(a)
input: What happens if a person fails to return goods in accordance with Clause 491?
output: Clause 491 states that if a person fails to return goods within the time-limit, the aggrieved person may recover the amount of such goods and a reasonable compensation for loss. Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Describe rights granted to the owner or possessor under Clause 491(a)
input: According to Clause 491, what rights does an owner or possessor have regarding returned goods?

Consult The Muluki Ain for authoritative interpretation.

instruction: Detail the procedure for returning goods under Clause 491(a)
